Nothing to do to save his life, call his wife in
This instance is an everyday occurrence for the perspective of the speaker, presumably a doctor of a sort. A man has died, so his next of kin, his wife, needs to be informed of this incidence.
Go to a show, you hope she goes

Biographers have long speculated that this line is in direct reference to Yoko Ono, who John first met at an art gallery. At the very least, it’s about an enticing woman who is not the protagonist’s wife.

Guten Morgen, guten Morgen, gut
 Guten Morgen, guten Morgen, gut
 Guten Morgen, guten Morgen, gut
 Guten Morgen, guten Morgen, gut (Ja! Ja!)
 
 Guten Morgen, guten Morgen, gut (Ja!)
 Guten Morgen, guten Morgen, gut (Gewözei teuer)
 Guten Morgen, guten Morgen, good morning

Towards the end of the song, The Beatles suddenly begin singing the German phrase for “good morning”, which is “guten Morgen”. Due to these phrases sounding similar, and the fact that animal noises in the track begin to drown out the vocals at this point, this is often misheard as more iterations of “good morning”. The vocal chart of the song in The Beatles: Rock Band confirms these lines, however.

Several other German utterances are shouted here: “ja” (“yes”) and “gewözei teuer” (“especially expensive”).

John had a rather peculiar idea for a way to end the song, as engineer Geoff Emerick recalls:

“John said to me during one of the breaks that he wanted to have the sound of animals escaping and that each successive animal should be capable of frightening or devouring its predecessor! So those are not just random effects, there was actually a lot of thought put into all that.”

The animals you can hear in the aural stampede are: Birds, Cats, Dogs, Cows, Horses, Sheep, Lions, Elephants, and a pack of bloodhounds accompanying fox hunters.

The sound effects were taken from the “Abbey Road sound effects tapes: Volume 35: Animals and Bees and Volume 57: Fox-hunt”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tGdrdui3Nqg

The song begins with the crowing of a cock, an archetypal symbol for the rising of the day.

Coincidentally (or intentionally) it is also the symbol for Cornflakes cereal:

Good morning, good morning
 Good morning, good morning
 Good morning

The Title and hook of this song were inspired by an early Kellogg’s Jingle:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8fF9WtAEEL0

Lennon on the matter:

“Good Morning is mine. It’s a throwaway, a piece of garbage, I always thought. The ‘Good morning, good morning’ was from a Kellogg’s cereal commercial. I always had the TV on very low in the background when I Was writing and it came over and then I wrote the song.”

Everybody knows there’s nothing doing
 Everything is closed, it’s like a ruin

Lennon was only singing about closing time, but unfortunately, since the song was released this has become too common a sight in the UK. Town centres are abandoned for out-of-town shopping centres, supermarkets, and internet shopping.
It’s time for tea and Meet the Wife

Tea Time is a popular trope of English culture.

John’s not going to meet his wife, rather he is making another reference to something on television

“Meet the Wife” was an old BBC sitcom.

As McCartney recalls:

“John was feeling trapped in suburbia and was going through some problems with Cynthia. It was about his boring life at the time – there’s a reference in the lyrics to ‘nothing to do’ and ‘meet the wife’; there was an afternoon TV soap called Meet The Wife that John watched, he was that bored, but I think he was also starting to get alarm bells.”
